Award.AwardTitle: STAMPS (Science, Technology and Math Preparation Scholarships)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The STAMPS (Science Technology and Math Preparation Scholarships) program is designed to meet the emerging need for a scientifically literate workforce in the Piedmont Triad of North Carolina, supporting 53 scholarship recipients in 4 cohorts of 11-16 students each. The Triad (Greensboro, High Point and Winston-Salem) forms an urban complex with a population of 1.6 million. The Triad's cultural, social, and economic history was closely tied with tobacco farming and cigarette manufacturing, furniture making, and textiles. In this 21st century, these industries are being replaced with pharmaceutical and technology companies.

STAMPS provides scholarships to students for the 4 years that they attend the University of North Carolina at Greensboro (UNCG), with later cohorts receiving support directly from the University after S-STEM funds are completed. Efforts target all of the fundamental sciences at UNCG - Mathematical Sciences, Computer Science, Chemistry and Biochemistry, Biology, Geographic Information Science and Earth Science, Physics and Astronomy - as well as the new Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering. A focus of the program is to recruit talented financially needy students (including women and minorities) into the scholarship program and to provide wide-ranging support to them during their college careers. Scholarship recipients are recruited from area high schools, from students matriculating through the state-supported community and technology colleges or transferring from other universities, and from the current UNCG student population. The STAMPS program focuses on cohorts of approximately 14 students that remain together for as many years as possible so that the resulting cross-disciplinary student community aids in student retention. The STAMPS design includes a freshman seminar, concurrent enrollment in mathematics classes, skill/career development activities, peer mentors, and tutors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the STAMPS (“Science, Technology and Math Preparation Scholarships”) Project are to provide financial and community support for undergraduate students at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro who are majoring in Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Earth Science and Geographic Information Systems, Mathematical Sciences, and Physics and Astronomy. Students are awarded scholarships based on a demonstration of both a significant promise for success in science/math and a measurable financial need. Ninety percent of our funding was scholarships.

Additionally, our goal is to have students graduate with degrees in STEM and continue on in either STEM related careers or further education.

STAMPS builds a supportive community for science students and faculty. The STAMPS students and faculty meet together to broaden students' knowledge of the interconnectedness of STEM disciplines, career opportunities, and exposure to cutting edge research. Students and faculty are invited to attend a broad range of interdisciplinary lectures and programs, visit scientific labs, engage in opportunities with graduate students, and network with other students to form a community of scientists. This past year we were able to take the STAMPS students on two field trips. In the fall we went to Stone Mountain, NC where students learned about their geological heritage. In April 2015, 19 of our STAMPS students went to Washington DC. The first day of this trip was spent at Goddard Space Center and the National Institute for Science and Technology. The second day students explored the Mall and various Smithsonian Institutions.

Throughout the life of the grant 98 students particiapted in STAMPS. At the end of Spring 2015 we had 21 active STAMPS students and 11 additional students graduated from UNCG with degrees in STEM. Overall, for those students who graduated and had received financial assistance from STAMPS, our 4 year graduation rate  was 68%. This is higher than any of the STEM disciplines on campus (for a 4 year graduation rate). STAMPS enabled many students to graduate within a 4 years,  and the scholarships allowed many to stop working and concentrate on their studies and university experience; even those students that continued to work, reported working fewer hours.

Many STAMPS students graduated with a 4.0 in a STEM discipline and all students in STAMPS, maintained at least a 3.5 GPA for the semesters that they received financial assistance (or were part of STAMPS). Through the National Clearinghouse, we were able to track down information on 82% (63 of 77)[1] of the students that graduated or left the program.

At the end of the grant, 21 students were still enrolled in STAMPS as undergraduates. Of the 77 students that graduated/left the program, we know that at least 89% (56 of 63)[2] had either entered a STEM discipline in higher education or were embarking upon a STEM career. Since we know only 3 students that switched out of STEM majors, some of the remaining 11% not in the 89% figure above may still eventually enter STEM fields.

For some students, STAMPS  was THE reason that they were able to attend University and continue their studies.  These are smart students who needed the scholarships to be able to work less outside of school and be involved in more research and university life. All STAMPS students  were grateful for their scholarships.  Many of our STAMPS graduates have gone on to careers or further STEM education or careers and their knowledge and expertise will continue to make an impact on the broader community.
